Events.OnCreate:
(switch ; If the player already has a damaged archcannon, we want to ; go straight to success status. But that is not possible so ; just force-accept the mission and use the InProgress dialog (objGetItems gPlayerShip "wD +qianlongArchcannon;") (msnAccept gSource)
; If the dragon slaver wreck still has an archcannon, we use ; the briefing screen to tell the player about it (disable intro) (filter (sysFindObject gSource "t") theObj (objGetItems theObj "w +qianlongArchcannon;")) (block Nil (msnSetProperty gSource 'isIntroShown True) (msnRegisterForEvents gSource gPlayerShip) )
; Otherwise no mission (msnDestroy gSource) )
Events.OnInProgress: (if (objGetItems gPlayerShip "wD +qianlongArchcannon;") (block Nil (msnSuccess gSource) ; Using InProgress dialog to debrief, so disable normal screen (msnSetProperty gSource 'isDebriefed True) ) )
Events.OnObjDocked: (if (and (= aObjDocked gPlayerShip) (= (objGetID aDockTarget) (msnGetProperty gSource 'ownerID)) (objGetItems gPlayerShip "wD +qianlongArchcannon;") ) (msnSuccess gSource) )

Language.Text: Look for a powerful weapon in the Dragon wreck.
"But perhaps there is a way we can make your path easier. Go to the wreck of the Dragon and there you will find a sword your enemies will fear."

Apotamo greets you at the door of the Grand Hall.
"Welcome back, %name%! Take your ease here before you continue on your arduous journey."

"I see you have found the Slaver's weapon. Perhaps there is a way in which we might repay the debt we owe you."
Apotamo leads you to a chamber inside the temple. You see row upon row of slave coffins, all connected together and to a vast array of optical computers.

"Not all slaves can be freed from the Sung's enslavement. Some are lost to us forever; we keep them here so they can continue their work—it is the only peace they know."
"The damaged archcannon you found on the slaver's wreck can be repaired by these poor souls."

You bring the archcannon to the slave chamber. You hear a cacophony of voices rise up from the slave coffins. A laser lattice envelops the archcannon and the computer displays flash blueprints and diagnostics. Robot hands expertly repair the device.
When the work is finished, the voices die away in a bittersweet tone of satisfaction.
